riskAreas.description: High-risk areas identified for mobile-first PWA domain
areas: Service Worker lifecycle and cache management
Cross-platform payment integration (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
Offline transaction handling and Background Sync
Browser and OS compatibility across mobile ecosystem

automationFitnessPatterns.description: Learned automation fitness mappings for PWA features

insights.e2eLevelDominance: 47% of test ideas require e2e-level testing due to browser API dependencies and complex user interactions (biometric, gestures, PWA install)
insights.integrationLevelUsage: 23% for Service Worker lifecycle, API contracts, third-party integrations
insights.securityTesting: 9% for payment security, credential management, permission handling
insights.performanceTesting: 6% for network conditions (Slow 3G), low-end device testing
insights.accessibilityTesting: 6% for WCAG compliance, screen reader support, alternative controls

priorityHeuristics.description: Heuristics for assigning priorities in mobile-first PWA context
P0Triggers: Direct revenue impact (payment failures, checkout blocking)
Security vulnerabilities (credential theft, payment data exposure)
Accessibility compliance violations (WCAG 2.2 Level AAA for touch targets)
Core PWA functionality broken (offline mode, Service Worker registration)
Network reliability issues on Slow 3G (depends on Epic 2 performance)
P1Triggers: Significant UX degradation (biometric fallback, gesture failures)
Browser compatibility gaps for major versions (Chrome, Safari, Firefox)
Performance metrics at risk (mobile conversion rate, PWA install rate)
P2Triggers: Polish features (status bar theming, splash screens, pinch-to-zoom)
Edge case handling (extreme lighting for barcode, foldable device adaptation)
Nice-to-have features (store mode, Web Share API, Periodic Background Sync)
P3Triggers: Rare scenarios (multiple PWA installs on same device)
Non-critical polyfills for very old browsers
Legacy browser support (IE11, pre-2015 mobile browsers)

clarifyingQuestionTemplates.description: Templates for generating clarifying questions by SFDIPOT category

templates.Structure: What is the technical implementation strategy for [feature]? Which specific libraries/frameworks? Fallback if unavailable?
templates.Function: What is the expected behavior when [feature] is unavailable or fails? What's the fallback strategy? How to handle graceful degradation?
templates.Data: What are the size/duration constraints for [data storage]? How to handle quota exceeded? Cache invalidation strategy?
templates.Interfaces: What is the exact integration flow with [third-party service]? Rate limits? Error handling and retry strategy?
templates.Platform: What is the minimum browser/OS version support? Strategy for handling unsupported platforms? Polyfills needed?
templates.Operations: What analytics/metrics should be tracked for [user workflow]? Accessibility requirements beyond WCAG? Privacy considerations?
templates.Time: What is the retry/timeout strategy for [background process]? Battery/performance constraints? How long to persist pending actions?

clarifyingQuestionTemplates.insights: Most clarifying questions (6) in Function category due to ambiguity around offline behavior and feature availability. Platform (4) and Time (4) also high due to browser/network variability and background process complexity.

keyDependencies: Epic 1 (Accessibility) - Touch target sizing, screen reader support
Epic 2 (Performance) - Slow 3G performance, Core Web Vitals
Service Worker API maturity across browsers
Payment provider integrations (Apple Pay, Google Pay)
crossPlatformChallenges: iOS PWA limitations (50MB cache, no Background Sync, limited push)
Browser API inconsistencies (Payment Request API not in Firefox)
Session sync complexity across mobile web, desktop, native app

testingComplexity.deviceFragmentation: Small screens (320px), tablets (768-1024px), foldables, low-end devices
testingComplexity.biometricVariety: Face ID, Touch ID, Android fingerprint, Android face unlock, none

automationChallenges: Biometric authentication requires physical device (cannot fully automate in CI)
PWA install flow varies by browser (Chrome A2HS vs Safari Add to Home Screen)
Camera API testing for barcode scanning requires mock camera input
Push notification testing requires integration with push service provider
Offline testing requires network throttling and Service Worker simulation

forFutureAssessments: Start with Function and Platform categories for PWA epics - highest question count
Pre-identify browser compatibility matrix early to estimate testing effort
Clarify offline behavior upfront - drives 20+ test ideas across categories
Map third-party integrations (payment, push, barcode) to separate workstreams
Estimate ~50% of PWA test ideas will require real device testing (not just browser automation)
forTestStrategy: Prioritize e2e testing on real devices for biometric, gestures, PWA install flows
Use BrowserStack/Sauce Labs for browser matrix coverage (30-50 configurations)
Implement Service Worker testing in integration test suite (cache strategies, lifecycle)
Create separate security test suite for payment, WebAuthn, permission handling
Build performance test suite for Slow 3G, low-end devices, network transitions
forStakeholderConversations: Schedule Product Coverage Session BEFORE development starts
Bring browser compatibility matrix to refinement - drives scope decisions
Discuss iOS PWA limitations upfront - may impact feature parity goals
Clarify success metrics (how to measure 10% PWA install rate, conversion rate)
Align on acceptable graceful degradation for unsupported browsers/devices
